0.summary: Ben S. Bernanke, in testimony to Congress, said that the Fed expected the economy to gain strength in the coming months, potentially allowing the Fed to decelerate its stimulus campaign.
0.title: Fed Chairman Reaffirms Economic Plan

1.summary: What you need to know for Wednesday: more diabolical weather, a phone warning startles many awake and a plague of mockingbird attacks in Brooklyn.
1.title: City Room: New York Today: Hotter Than …

2.summary: Technically speaking, skinny-dipping is illegal in the city, but that has not stopped swimmers from taking the risk and baring it all.
2.title: Summer Shorelines: Daring Enough to Bare It All for a New York Swim

3.summary: President Vladmir V. Putin said Wednesday that bilateral relations were more important than the controversy surrounding Edward J. Snowden, the former intelligence contractor.
3.title: Putin Does Not Expect Ties With U.S. to Be Harmed by Snowden Case

4.summary: The authorities were searching for the headmistress of a primary school in the eastern state of Bihar after children were served food contaminated with insecticide.
4.title: India Ink: 21 Children Die From Tainted Lunches at Indian School

5.summary: The police said a boy was kidnapped by his mother during a visit at a social service facility, leading officials to send an emergency message that set off cellphones across the city.
5.title: Early Morning Alert Issued After 7-Month-Old Boy Is Abducted

6.summary: China’s domestic economic balance is precarious, the fund said, largely a result of too little consumer spending and too much government spending.
6.title: I.M.F. Tells China of Urgent Need for Economic Change

7.summary: Joaquín Almunia, the European Union competition commissioner, said Google’s proposals to address antitrust concerns were “not enough.”
7.title: Europe Wants More Concessions From Google

8.summary: As a bioethicist, Peggy Battin fought for the right of people to end their own lives. After her husband’s cycling accident, her field of study turned unbearably personal.
8.title: A Life-or-Death Situation

9.summary: Xu Zhiyong, who was held Tuesday on unlawful assembly charges, has challenged the Communist Party to act on its vows to expose corruption and respect the rule of law.
9.title: China Detains a Leading Human Rights Advocate

10.summary: A scandal surrounding the Olympic sport of rhythmic gymnastics has implicated as many as 60 experts of the sport who were looking to qualify as official judges.
10.title: Judges of a Graceful Sport, Caught in a Clumsy Cheating Scandal

11.summary: Mohamed Dirrar Jammo, a prominent Syrian commentator and staunch defender of the government of President Bashar al-Assad, was gunned down Wednesday at his home.
11.title: Assad Supporter Killed by Gunmen in Southern Lebanon

12.summary: Mohammed Darrar Jammo, a political analyst who often defended Syrian leaders on Arab TV stations, was gunned down on Wednesday inside his home.
12.title: Pro-Government Syrian Analyst Killed in Lebanon

13.summary: Young people who work making iPhones and other electronic devices in China flock to nightclubs in their time off, desperately trying to enjoy the present as they strive for a better future.
13.title: Zhengzhou Journal: The Demanding Off-Hour Escapes of China’s High-Tech Workers

14.summary: The Mets’ Matt Harvey made his All-Star debut to a hometown crowd, but it was Mariano Rivera of the Yankees, playing in his 13th and final All-Star Game, who sealed the win for the American League.
14.title: American 3, National 0: For Rivera, an Ending to Savor

15.summary: Individuals buying health insurance on their own will see their premiums tumble next year in New York State, and supporters of the health care overhaul credit the online purchasing exchanges the law created.
15.title: Health Plan Cost for New Yorkers Set to Fall 50%

16.summary: The move to bring back Keith Olbermann, a former co-anchor at ESPN, was the result of 14 months of intense discussion within the network and its parent, the Walt Disney Company.
16.title: Olbermann Will Return To ESPN

17.summary: Charities had not disbursed almost $240 million of the $575 million in contributions they had received to help victims of the storm, according to a survey conducted at the end of March.
17.title: State Questions Charities on Flow of Hurricane Aid

18.summary: Mayor Bob Filner, a Democrat, has been besieged by a blizzard of sexual harassment charges by employees and constituents.
18.title: In San Diego, Mayor Rejects Calls by Allies to Step Down

19.summary: The White House is tapping into a huge and politically powerful audience: the millions of viewers who watch Univision and Telemundo.
19.title: White House Focuses on Reaching Latino Viewers

20.summary: Lawmakers amended the law three weeks after the United States announced plans to suspend Bangladesh’s trade privileges over labor rights and safety violations in factories.
20.title: Under Pressure, Bangladesh Adopts New Labor Law

21.summary: The Senate’s confirmation of Richard Cordray to lead the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau cemented the agency’s broad regulatory authority.
21.title: Vote Ushers In New Era in Oversight of Lending Practices

22.summary: After the $3.4 billion Columbia River Crossing plan was killed by the Washington State Senate, leaders in Vancouver, Wash., and Portland, Ore., picked up the ball.
22.title: Washington and Oregon Cities Try to Evade Political Jam to Build a Bridge

23.summary: With the arrest of the feared Zeta crime boss Miguel Ángel Treviño Morales, Mexico’s long and bloody drug war may have reached a crossroads.
23.title: Capture of Mexican Crime Boss Appears to End a Brutal Chapter

-1.summary: Bank of America’s net income rose to $4 billion, or 32 cents a share, from $2.5 billion, or 19 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
-1.title: DealBook: Bank of America Profit Rises 63%
